metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Changes in sexual behaviors of young women and men during the coronavirus disease 2019 outbreak: a convenience sample from the epidemic area Changes in sexual behaviors of young women and men during the coronavirus disease 2019 outbreak: a convenience sample from the epidemic area

body_text.text: Outcomes: The study outcomes were obtained using a study-specific questionnaire to 17 assess the changes in people's sexual behavior. analysis showed that age, partner relationship and sexual desire were closely related to sexual frequency. In addition, we found that most individuals with risky sexual 23 experiences had a rapid reduction in risky sexual behavior.

Clinical Implications: The current findings contribute to identifying another 25 potential health implication associated with the COVID-19 pandemic and report 26 preliminary evidence of the need to provide potential interventions for the population.

This study is the first to perform a preliminary exploration 28 of sexual behavior during the COVID-19 outbreak. The generalizability of the results 29 is limited, given that only a small convenience sample was used.

The coronavirus disease (COVID-19) has already been declared a global 38 pandemic, having infected more than 200000 people in over 100 countries 1 . activities, which is in agreement with previous studies 6 . 120 In addition, we found that most individuals with a history of risky sexual

FIGREF0.text: In March 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared 7 coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), which is caused by the severe acute 8 respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), a pandemic. Currently, data on 9 changes in sexual behavior during the COVID-19 outbreak are limited.

FIGREF1.text: The present study aimed to obtain a preliminary understanding of the changes in 11 people's sexual behavior, as a result of the pandemic and explore the context in which 12 they manifest.

FIGREF2.text: Methods: A convenience sample of 270 men and 189 women who completed an 14 online survey consisting of 12 items plus an additional question were included in the 15 study.

FIGREF4.text: While there was a wide range of individual responses, our results showed 19 that 44% of participants reported a decrease in the number of sexual partners and 20 about 37% of participants reported a decrease in sexual frequency. Multiple regression 21

FIGREF5.text: During the height of the COVID-19 outbreak, overall sexual activity, 31 frequency, and risky behaviors declined significantly among young men and women 32 in China.

FIGREF6.text: February to early March 2020, most provinces in China closed all 40 workplaces (including schools) that provided non-essential services, and all 41 employees and students worked from home. The government strictly managed the 42 movement and gathering of people, and restrictions on non-essential social activities 43 were strictly enforced. The outbreak of COVID-19 and series of strict control measures adopted by the government had many negative effects on individuals and 45 society. The population may experience restriction of activities, panic, poor mental 46 health, loss of relatives, life-threatening situations, unemployment, reduced income, 47 and separation from their families or partners 2 . Individuals may also experience 48 unique changes in their sexual behaviors under these unprecedented conditions 3 . 49However, sexual behaviors during the COVID-19 pandemic have not been examined.

FIGREF7.text: 13 to 15, 2020, a brief online survey was administered to 55 participants recruited in China. A total of 600 men and 600 women were invited to 56 complete self-management surveys via social media platforms. 57 Before receiving the questionnaire, the participants were informed that the 58 anonymous survey was about sexual behaviors, contained personal questions, and 59 required approximately 5 minutes to complete. Participants were offered 60 approximately $2 to complete the survey. This research was approved by the 61 Academic Ethics Committee of Anhui Medical University. All participants approved 62 an electronic informed consent. 63 Participants completed a 12-item questionnaire that included questions assessing 64 the participants' demographics and present and previous sexual behaviors. The 65 following data were obtained using a self-constructed, study-specific instrument: age, 66 ethnicity, education, profession, current financial situation, sexual orientation, sexually transmitted disease status, self and partner medical and surgical history, 68 partner relationship, living together with parents or not, changes in the number of 69 sexual partners, sexual desire, frequency of sexual behavior, sexual satisfaction, and 70 risky sexual behaviors. Symptoms were assessed for "during the COVID-19 71 outbreak". Apart from that, an additional question was raised: Do you intend to 72 increase the number of sexual partners or risky sexual behaviors (defined as 73 inconsistent condom use, "casual" sexual partnerships, or multiple sexual partnerships) 74 after the outbreak is over? 75 A missed answer reminder was added to ensure the integrity of the data, and 76 incomplete questionnaires were not submitted to the system. Of the 1,200 participants 77 who received the survey, 305 (50.8%) men and 248 women (41.3%) completed the 78 entire questionnaire. Participants aged 18-45 years, with a history of sexual activity, 79 who provided informed consent were included in the study. Participants or their 80 partners who were diagnosed with systemic diseases (n = 23), mental disorders (n = 81 12), sexually transmitted diseases (n = 9), and other serious conditions that led to 82 sexual dysfunction or were taking any drugs that altered sexual function (n = 14, 83 including alcohol abuse and drug use) were excluded 4, 5 . Homosexual or bisexual 84 individuals (n = 7) and pregnant and lactating women (n = 29) were also excluded 85 from the study.

FIGREF8.text: . The characteristics of the study population are presented inTable 1. Most 91 interviewees (72%) lived with their parents. Approximately half of the participants 92 (55%) experienced financial deterioration during the COVID-19 outbreak. 93 According to the present study, 25% of the participants experienced reduction in 94 sexual desire, while only 18% of men and 8% of women experienced increased sexual 95 desire. The difference between men and women was statistically significant (F = 96 12.09, df = 2, p = 0.002), and the difference reported here is attributed to the decrease 97 (F = 3.99, df = 1, p = 0.046) and increase (F = 10.28, df = 1, p = 0.001) in the desire 98 (compared to unchanged). The results showed that 44% of participants reported a 99 decrease in the number of sexual partners, with men slightly more likely than women 100 to report a decrease in the number of sexual partners (53% vs. 30%). There was good 101 agreement between men and women in terms of sexual frequency, with about 37% of 102 participants reporting decreased sexual frequency. A sub-analysis of married 103 individuals showed that all participants had similar characteristics, 49% of married 104 men and 29% of married women reported a decrease in the number of sexual partners 105 and 36% of married men and 28% of married women reported a decrease in the 106 frequency of sexual activities. Through multiple regression analysis, we found that 107 age, partner relationship, and sexual desire were closely related to sexual frequency 108 (Table 2). During the COVID-19 outbreak, 32% of men and 39% of women 109 experienced a reduction in sexual satisfaction. The difference between men and women was statistically significant (F = 14.49, df = 2, p = 0.001). In addition, most participants with a history of risky sexual experiences had a reduction in risky sexual 112 behaviors after the COVID-19 outbreak. In fact, only five individuals reported an 113 increase in risky behaviors during this period. general, at the height of the COVID-19 epidemic, we found that both sexual 117 activities and sexual satisfaction of young men and women decreased. Low sexual 118 desire and unsatisfying partner relationships were significant factors affecting sexual 119

FIGREF9.text: 121 experiences had a rapid reduction in risky sexual behaviors. This may be because the 122 participants may have experienced a great deal of psychological stress during this 123 particular period, such as anxiety, fear, boredom, and disappointment. In addition, it is 124 undeniable that strict physical restrictions have directly impacted the possibility of 125 having new sexual partners and risky sexual behaviors. However, in the 126 supplementary question, 32% of men and 18% of women indicated that they were 127 inclined to increase the number of sexual partners or risky sexual behaviors once the 128 epidemic ended. A significant minority will be engaged in behaviors that could 129 increase the risk of contracting sexually transmitted diseases 7 .

FIGREF10.text: There are several potential limitations to our research that should be noted. First, 131 race and ethnic culture appear to have a significant association with the occurrence of sexual problems 8 . For example, most young Chinese people live with their parents (72% 133 in the current study), which is different from results reported in other countries and 134 may be a significant factor that can limit their sexual behaviors. Therefore, the small135 sample size from a single ethnicity and the lack of randomization are also limitations 136 for the extrapolation of the results to the global general population. Second, the use of 137 unverified questionnaires and retrospective evaluations of sexual behavior was also a 138 weakness of the study. In addition, we did not collect data form participants who did 139 not complete the questionnaire. Hence, the characteristics of these individuals and 140 their impact on the overall data were not analyzed. knowledge, this may be the first study on sexual behavior during the 144 COVID-19 outbreak. The current results show that overall sexual activity, frequency, 145 and risky behaviors declined significantly among young men and women during this 146 unique time. Therefore, as an aspect of overall health, sexual health suffered impacts 147 during the COVID-19 pandemic and that this represents one potential area to be 148 recognized and addressed by sexual health experts.149 150 Conflict of Interest: The authors report no conflicts of interest.

back_matter.text: We would like to thank all participants.
